Author: mithro_
Content: @carlfk - I'm going to rework my home network so that the fpgas and IPs stay at 10.31.X.X rather than having to move to 10.41.X.X which should reduce the curn in the pici ansible

Author: carlfk
Content: im still curious what you are trying to do

Author: mithro_
Content: Oh, wait it looks like pici uses 10.21.X.X ?

Author: mithro_
Content: I'm trying to fit an "isolated network" of the fpgas.online hardware into my home network which is also trying isolate the supermicro BMC/coreboot hardware, the IoT network, the guest network and such. The goal is to prevent accidental exposure of my servers to devices which random people can connect too.

Author: carlfk
Content: the PIs and everyting else on the same PoE switch?

Author: mithro_
Content: Internet --> ten64.welland.mithis.com (gateway machine) --> Random networking hardware --> tweed --> PoE switch --> RPis

Author: mithro_
Content: @carlfk - And unlike in the US, I only have one public static IPv4 address rather than a small number of them.

Author: carlfk
Content: I suspect it will be easier to put tweed in place of ten64

Author: carlfk
Content: but if you have figured out how to tunnel to tweed, good.

Author: mithro_
Content: @carlfk - I can't do that because I need ten64 for my home network. As I said, unlike in Sunnyvale where I could give tweed a public IPv4 address I can't do that here.

Author: mithro_
Content: I also have the problem that tweed and the fpgas are a *long* way away from the internet ingress point, so there is a bunch of networking equipment between the gateway and tweed.

Author: carlfk
Content: long = too long for a run of cat5?

Author: carlfk
Content: im not really sure what the real limit is

Author: carlfk
Content: is outgoing byte count something to wory about?

Author: carlfk
Content: the home page of videos are not scaled server side - I send the full res and the player is shurnk

Author: mithro_
Content: I think a cat6 cable might just reach but it'll be a while before I can run that cable.
